projects.name: Assemble the Bedroom

steps.instruction: Glue the wall to the floor: Apply glue to the top of the right-hand side tab of the wall piece and attach the circular floor piece to that tab (do not attach the other side of the floor yet).
steps.visual_description: The wall piece is being glued to the circular floor piece on the right-hand side tab.

steps.instruction: Glue footboard: Glue the footboard piece in position on the bed piece.
steps.visual_description: The footboard piece is being glued onto the bed piece.

steps.instruction: Attach the bed to the wall: Apply glue to the bed tab that folds down under the pillows and glue it in place on the right-hand wall, aligning the bottom of the piece with the right angle of the floor and centering it left to right between the center fold and the nightstand.
steps.visual_description: The bed piece is being glued to the right-hand wall, aligning its bottom with the floor's right angle and centering it between the center fold and nightstand.

steps.instruction: Attach the bed to the floor: Fold the bed piece up against the wall and put a small glue dot on the small base tab of the bed piece. Fold up the circular floor piece, attaching the floor to the small bed tab. Make sure that the tab attaches only to the right side of the floors center fold.
steps.visual_description: The bed piece is folded up, and its base tab is glued to the circular floor piece on the right side of the floor's center fold.

steps.instruction: Glue the headboard: Apply glue to the back of the headboard and attach it to the wall.
steps.visual_description: The headboard is being glued to the wall.

steps.instruction: Attach the lamp and curtain: Make one large paper spring for the lamp and two small paper springs for the curtain (see Making a Paper Spring on page 72). Glue the large spring to the back of the lamp and the two smaller springs to the back top corners of the curtain. Apply glue to the backs of the springs and attach the fixtures in position on the walls.
steps.visual_description: A large paper spring is glued to the back of the lamp, and two smaller springs are glued to the top corners of the curtain. These are then attached to the walls.

steps.instruction: Finish the floor: Glue the other side of the floor piece to the back wall tab. Fold the page carefully to make sure that everything moves properly.
steps.visual_description: The remaining side of the floor piece is glued to the back wall tab. The page is then folded to test movement.

tips: Make sure that the tab attaches only to the right side of the floors center fold.
Fold the page carefully to make sure that everything moves properly.
projects.finished_product_description: An assembled bedroom scene within a pop-up structure, featuring a bed, nightstand, lamp, and curtain.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up bedroom scene with a bed, nightstand, lamp hanging from the ceiling, and a picture frame on the wall.
A hand attaching a tab to a circular piece of paper, labeled 'B'.
A hand using a paintbrush to apply glue to a piece of paper, labeled 'C'.
A hand attaching a paper spring to a fixture on a pop-up structure, labeled 'D'.

projects.name: Assemble the Kitchen

steps.instruction: Attach the floor: Apply glue to the top of the right-hand side tab of the wall piece and attach the circular floor piece to that tab. Glue the left-hand side of the floor to the wall tab.

Affix chairs to walls and floors: Apply glue to the bottom of the base of one chair and glue it to the right-hand side of the floor, off-center and to the right, with the tab tucked up against the wall. Collapse the chair flat onto the floor, and apply glue to the upper back of the chair. Keeping the chair collapsed, fold the floor piece up so that it meets the wall, pressing the glued segment of the chair onto the wall. Attach the second chair to the other wall using the same method, adhering it in the center of the wall.
steps.visual_description: Two chairs are attached to the walls and floor of the pop-up kitchen scene.

steps.instruction: Construct the table: Assemble the small support piece. Cut the two slits as indicated and glue the middle segment of the table support together, leaving the tabs at each end unglued. Glue the tabs on one end of the support to the center of the underside of the table legs. Glue the two parts of the tabletop to the top of the table legs. (The tabletop is cut into two pieces and attached separately; otherwise, there is too much buildup and the table will not open flat.) Glue the base tabs of the table legs to the tabs of the table support. Glue the base tabs of the table legs to the floor, centering them on either side of the fold in the floor.
steps.visual_description: A table is constructed and attached to the floor of the pop-up scene.

steps.instruction: Attach the lamp to the wall with a spring: Make a small paper spring (see Making a Paper Spring on this page) and glue the spring to the back of the lamp piece. Glue the lamp and spring in place on the wall.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up kitchen scene with chairs and a table.

projects.name: Making a Paper Spring

steps.instruction: To make a spring, overlap two rectangular strips of paper that are the same size and glue them together in the corner so that they are at right angles to each other. Snugly fold the lower paper strip over the top one (which then becomes the lower strip) and continue in this fashion, lower strip over upper strip, until the paper has been folded into a little square spring.
steps.visual_description: Two paper strips are overlapped at a right angle and glued. Then, the lower strip is folded over the upper strip, and this process is repeated to form a spring.

projects.finished_product_description: A small square paper spring.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram A shows a hand holding a red paper structure, with a small white bottle of glue and a green pencil on the table. The paper structure appears to be a pop-up element being assembled.
Diagram B shows a pop-up scene of a kitchen interior with two chairs and a table. A white bottle of glue and a green pencil are also visible.
A photograph shows a partially assembled paper spring, with several folded segments visible, and a completed small square spring. The background is a light beige surface.

projects.name: Outdoor Grill

steps.instruction: Attach the floor piece to the wall piece: Glue the folded floor piece to the top of both tabs on the wall piece.
steps.visual_description: The text describes attaching a folded floor piece to tabs on a wall piece.

steps.instruction: Prepare the chimney and attach the grill: Before folding the grill, cut the two slits on the sides of the chimney. Glue the base of the grill onto the left side of the floor panel, near the outer edge of the wall so that the outside corner of the grill is touching the edge of the circular floor panel.
steps.visual_description: The text describes cutting slits on a chimney and gluing the grill base to the floor panel, aligning it with the edge of a circular floor panel.

steps.instruction: Collapse the grill onto the floor panel and apply glue to the two middle tabs and the upper tab (make sure that you can see the black top of the chimney when it is folded flat). Fold up the wall/floor piece, pressing the glued tabs onto the wall.
steps.visual_description: The text describes collapsing the grill, applying glue to tabs, and folding up the wall/floor piece.

steps.instruction: Stretch the coil of smoke between the chimney and the wall: Put a dab of glue on the outer end of the smoke coil and attach it to the wall at the top of the grill, aligning the flat edge of the coil end with the top of the chimney. Make sure that the entire coil is on the left side of the center fold of the wall and trim the coil if needed.
steps.visual_description: The text describes attaching a smoke coil to the chimney and wall, ensuring it's on the left side of the center fold.

steps.instruction: Put a small glue dot on the inner end of the smoke coil and close the wall/floor piece to attach the smoke coil to the other side of the wall.
steps.visual_description: The text describes applying glue to the inner end of the smoke coil and closing the wall/floor piece.

steps.instruction: Attach the tree to the center fold: Glue one long tab of the tree piece to one side of the wall at the center fold, aligning the top of the tree to the top of the wall. Glue the other long tab to the other side of the wall at the center fold. Glue the two leaf pieces to either side of the tree piece near the top, making sure that the leaf pieces do not
steps.visual_description: The text describes attaching a tree piece with long tabs to the center fold of a wall, aligning the top, and then gluing leaf pieces to the sides of the tree.

projects.finished_product_description: An assembled outdoor grill with a chimney and smoke, and an assembled outdoor laundry scene with a tree and clothes hanging.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up scene of an outdoor grill with a brick chimney and smoke coming out. The grill has an 'XX' design on the front. The scene is viewed from the front.
A close-up view of hands applying glue to small tabs inside a pop-up structure, likely part of the grill assembly.

projects.name: Pop-Up Book Assembly

steps.instruction: Attach the floor: Glue the folded floor piece to the top of both tabs on the wall piece.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up structure with a folded floor piece being attached to tabs on a wall piece.

steps.instruction: Sew the threads: Poke four holes through the wall marked on the clothesline. Thread a large needle with heavy thread and starting from the back of the left-hand wall, sew through the hole closest to the fold of the wall. Glue the end of the thread to the back of the wall to hold it in place. Bring the thread across to the other wall, threading it through the hole closest to the fold. Bring the thread back into the page by sewing through the wall and then thread it through the last hole, taking it to the back side again. Adjust the tension in the thread to allow the wall/floor piece to open fully without the threads sagging. Trim the thread and glue the end to the back of the wall. The span of thread on the other wall can also be glued down.
steps.visual_description: A hand sewing a thread through holes on a pop-up wall structure, with a clothesline visible. Another image shows a finished pop-up with clothes hanging on threads.

steps.instruction: Glue the various laundry pieces over the threads using the individual tabs.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up structure with small laundry pieces being glued onto threads.

steps.instruction: Assemble the book: Connect the rooms: Connect the rooms to each other by applying glue to the tabs on the right side of the first three rooms. The Outdoor Laundry Room has no tab and will be the last room added to the book.
steps.visual_description: A hand applying glue to tabs on the side of a pop-up room structure, preparing to connect it to another room.

steps.instruction: Make book covers: Cut two pieces of binder's board to 7" x 3 3/4" (17.8 x 9.5 cm), the same size that the walls are when folded shut. Cut two pieces of paper to 8" x 4 3/4" (20.3 x 12 cm) to cover the boards. Apply glue to one of the pieces of binder's board and affix
steps.visual_description: A hand applying glue to a piece of binder's board, with a piece of paper and a blue paper piece nearby. Another image shows a pop-up room with a light fixture.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up book with various rooms, including an outdoor laundry room with clothes hanging on a line.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram B shows a hand threading a needle through holes on a pop-up structure, with a clothesline and drawn trees visible.
Diagram C shows a pop-up structure with clothes hanging on threads from a clothesline.
Diagram A shows a pop-up room with a red interior and a light fixture, with a hand holding a brush and glue nearby.
Diagram B shows a hand applying glue to a piece of binder's board, with a blue paper piece and a white paper piece visible.

projects.name: Carousel Book

steps.instruction: Trim the corners of the cover papers (this is called mitering the corners).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of hands mitering the corners of a blue paper covering a board.

steps.instruction: Carefully glue one edge at a time and fold the cover paper over onto the binders board. Repeat with the other board to make the second cover.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a blue paper over a board, showing the process of covering the board.

steps.instruction: Measure and cut two sheets of rectangular paper to fill in the spaces on the back side of each covered board to reduce warping of the glued boards.

Attach the boards to the front and back of the two outer rooms by applying a small bead of glue around the edges of the boards. Alternatively, you can use double-sided tape. Attach a title panel if you desire.

tips: To display the book in the round, build in a mechanism for holding the covers together.
Two ideas for holding covers together: embed tiny magnets in the binder's board prior to covering the boards with paper, or attach to ribbons between the end walls and the covers.
projects.finished_product_description: A carousel book that can be displayed as an accordion or in the round, featuring scenery flats, a floating island, spring mechanisms, and layered elements.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up photograph shows hands mitering the corners of a blue paper that is being applied to a white board, with a paintbrush visible in the upper right corner.
A pop-up carousel book is shown open, displaying a scene with clothes hanging on a line, trees, and furniture like a table and chairs. The book has red and blue covers and a checkered floor pattern.

projects.name: Playing with Pop-Ups

tools.name: craft knife
tools.purpose: cutting mat board and card stock

steps.instruction: Take one piece of mat board and draw a border on the back measuring 3/4" (2 cm) on the top and sides and 1" (2.5 cm) on the bottom. Cut along these lines to create a frame and mark "top" on the back of the frame.
steps.visual_description: A mat board frame is cut out, with a ruler and pen visible nearby on a green cutting mat. Another mat board frame is also visible.

steps.instruction: Using the mat board frame as a template, trace the window shape onto two pieces of 4" x 6" (10.2 x 15.2 cm) card stock and then cut out the two windows. Mark "top" on the back of each one.
steps.visual_description: Two pieces of card stock with window shapes traced onto them. One piece of card stock has been cut out, showing a window. A mat board frame is used as a template.

steps.instruction: Download the bird and branch patterns (or enlarge and photocopy the templates on page 140) and print them onto the back side of appropriately colored card stocks. Fold the paper in half to save on work time and cut two birds at a time. Cut small triangles from scrap paper for the beaks and glue the beaks and wings onto the birds. Add eyes and other embellishments to the birds and branches.
steps.technique: downloading, printing, folding, cutting, gluing, embellishing
steps.visual_description: Several folded pieces of colored card stock (red, yellow, blue) with bird and branch shapes traced onto them. One brown branch shape is cut out. A pair of yellow scissors and a pen are on the table. A small blue bird cut-out is also visible.

steps.instruction: Lay out the pages of the book: the back cover (solid mat board), the front cover (mat board frame), and the two inside paper frames. Position the birds and branches on the frames to create the scene as shown, or play around with your own positioning. Glue the bird and branch pieces onto the front cover, inside frames, and back cover.
steps.visual_description: Four black card stock pieces with rectangular openings (frames). The top left frame is empty. The top right frame has a red bird on a brown branch. The bottom left frame has a yellow bird on a brown branch. The bottom right frame has a yellow bird and a blue bird on a brown branch. A paintbrush is visible at the bottom.

tips: Enlarge and photocopy templates on page 140 if needed.
Fold paper in half to cut two birds at a time.
Play around with your own positioning for the scene.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up book with scenes featuring birds on branches within mat board frames.

templates.name: Bird and Branch Patterns
templates.shape_description: Patterns for birds and branches to be cut from card stock.

projects.name: Tunnel Book

steps.instruction: Fold one of the side hinge papers in half, short side to short side. Unfold, turn it over, and fold each edge in to the center to create an accordion fold that looks like an M. Place an X on one of the end panels. Repeat with the remaining five hinge pieces.
steps.visual_description: Image 5 shows four folded gray paper pieces, a ruler, and a pen. The folded pieces are arranged to show an accordion fold. One piece has an 'X' marked on it.

steps.instruction: Assemble the book from front to back: A. Place the front cover facedown on your work surface. Take one hinge piece and glue the panel marked X to the edge of the cover, orienting it so that the first fold on the accordion-folded hinge lines up with the outside edge of the cover. Repeat this process on the opposite side of the cover, attaching a second hinge. B. Hold the first inner frame facedown (making sure the top is oriented properly) and slip it in between the last two folds on both sides of the hinge. Carefully apply glue to the back side of the last hinge panel and glue the hinge onto the back of the frame on both sides: Dont be too concerned if the exposed panels fail to line up exactly with the edges of the framepush the edges of the frame snuggly into the folds of the side hinges on both sides and glue the frame in place. When complete, the hinges will fall into place nicely. Repeat steps A and B to attach the next inner frame and then the back cover, making sure that each piece is properly oriented before gluing in place.
steps.visual_description: Image 6A shows a hand using a brush to apply glue to a gray paper hinge piece. A black frame with a paper bird and branch illustration is visible in the background. Image 6B shows a hand applying glue to a gray paper hinge piece that is being attached to a black frame with paper illustrations of a bird and branches.

optional_steps: Add a text sheet to the back of the book and/or a title label on the front cover. You can also incorporate text into the pages of the book.

diagram_descriptions: Image 5 shows four folded gray paper pieces, a ruler, and a pen. The folded pieces are arranged to show an accordion fold. One piece has an 'X' marked on it.
Image 6A shows a hand using a brush to apply glue to a gray paper hinge piece. A black frame with a paper bird and branch illustration is visible in the background.
Image 6B shows a hand applying glue to a gray paper hinge piece that is being attached to a black frame with paper illustrations of a bird and branches.

projects.name: Papercraft Dog

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Assemble the papercraft dog by folding and gluing the numbered pieces according to the diagram.

projects.finished_product_description: A 3D papercraft dog with black spots and a red mouth.

projects.name: Puppy Puppet

steps.instruction: Download the pattern (or enlarge and photocopy the templates on page 136) and print it onto card stock. Make sure the numbers appear on the tabs on the front side and on the areas on the back. You can write the numbers onto the template if they werent printed because they wont be visible on the final puppy.
Use markers, colored pencils, or crayons to illustrate the front of the finger puppet. Use the template as a guide for illustrating the various body parts.

Cut the puppet out along the solid black lines. Score along all of the lines that indicate folds. Mountain-fold each scored line except for the fold in the center of the puppys mouth, which is a valley fold.

Glue tab 1 on the front to area 1 on the back, aligning the folded edges and creating the rectangular space. Finish forming the puppys head by gluing tab 2 on the front to area 2 on the back. Glue tabs 3 and 4 on the front to areas 3 and 4 on the back. Finish forming the puppys body by gluing tab 5 on the front to area 5 on the back.
Slide your fingers into the back of the finger puppet and move them to make the mouth open and close.

projects.finished_product_description: An adorable movable finger puppet of a puppy.

templates.name: Puppy Puppet Template
templates.shape_description: Pattern with numbered tabs and areas for assembly.

diagram_descriptions: A hand holding a finished puppy finger puppet. The puppet is white with black spots, has large eyes, and a pink tongue sticking out. It is shown in a way that suggests its mouth can open and close. A circled number '5' is visible near the top of the puppet.

steps.instruction: Cut out the rib cage shape from the light blue card stock and cut out the red card stock base, which has a printed rib cage outline. Also cut out two small red strips for the pull tab mechanism.

steps.instruction: Fold the red card stock base in half. Attach the two small red strips to the inside of the folded card, positioned to create a pull tab mechanism.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding the folded red card stock base and attaching two small red strips to the inside, with the light blue rib cage cut-out positioned above.

steps.instruction: Glue the light blue rib cage cut-out onto the red card stock base, aligning it with the printed outline and the pull tab mechanism.
steps.visual_description: A hand carefully gluing the light blue rib cage cut-out onto the red card stock base, which is partially folded and has the red pull tab strips attached.

projects.name: Pull-Tab Rib Cage

materials.notes: for base card and rib cage, see page 138 or download patterns

steps.instruction: Photocopy a dictionary page onto card stock to create a background for the rib cage. Alternatively, use plain card stock, purchase printed card stock, illustrate the background, or make a collage to accent the ribs. Download the patterns for the base card and rib cage (or enlarge and photocopy the templates on page 138) and print them onto your prepared card stock.

Cut out the card base, the two rib cage side pieces, and the rib cage using a craft knife. Cut the three slits in the card base. Score along the central dotted line on the card base and valley-fold it in half. Score along the dashed lines on the two rib cage side pieces and mountain-fold each one along those lines.
Glue the inside of both folded rib cage side pieces, gluing both sides of the fold and sandwiching the matching sides of the rib cage into the glued areas.

Thread the strap through the right-hand slit in the card base from front to back and then thread it back into the card through the slit along the dotted line. Carefully lift the left side of the rib cage and apply glue to the back side of the rib cage side piece. Attach it to the base along the dotted line, taking care not to get glue on the strap.

Tuck the loose end of the strap into the slit on the left side of the base while folding the base page in half. Close the card completely, fold the end of the strap over, and glue it to the card base. Let the glue dry briefly. Open the card and watch your rib cage slide into three dimensions!

details.position: one right-hand, one along dotted line, one left-hand

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The project uses a pull-tab cylinder technique. The card base is folded in half. Rib cage side pieces are mountain-folded. The rib cage is sandwiched into the glued areas of the side pieces. A strap is threaded through slits in the card base and attached to the rib cage and the base to create the pop-up mechanism.

tips: For the background, you can use a plain card stock, purchase a printed card stock, illustrate it, or make a collage.
When attaching the rib cage to the base, take care not to get glue on the strap.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up rib cage that raises from the flat surface into three dimensions as the card spread is opened by a strap pulling a tab.

projects.name: Orange Slice Card

steps.instruction: Cut a circle from the white cardstock, approximately 5 inches in diameter. Cut a slit from the edge to the center of the circle.
steps.visual_description: A white cardstock circle with a slit from the edge to the center.

steps.instruction: Cut the patterned paper into 8 wedge shapes, resembling orange slices. Each wedge should be approximately 2 inches wide at the base and taper to a point.
steps.visual_description: Eight wedge-shaped pieces of light blue paper with pink outlines.

steps.instruction: Cut 8 small triangles from the light pink cardstock, approximately 1 inch on each side.
steps.visual_description: Eight small pink triangles.

steps.instruction: Glue the pink triangles onto the wider edge of the patterned paper wedges, alternating sides.
steps.visual_description: Pink triangles attached to the wide edges of the patterned paper wedges.

steps.instruction: Cut a small circle from the light pink cardstock, approximately 1 inch in diameter, for the center.
steps.visual_description: A small pink circle.

steps.instruction: Assemble the orange slices by inserting the slit of the white cardstock circle into itself to form a cone shape. Then, glue the patterned paper wedges around the outside of the cone, starting from the base and working upwards. Glue the small pink circle to the center of the assembled orange slice.
steps.visual_description: A layered circular paper craft resembling an orange slice, with a central pink circle and radiating wedges.

steps.instruction: Cut a square piece of white cardstock, approximately 6x6 inches, and cut a circular opening in the center, slightly larger than the assembled orange slice.
steps.visual_description: A white square card with a circular cutout in the center.

steps.instruction: Insert the assembled orange slice into the opening of the white card. Secure with a small strip of light blue paper on the back.
steps.visual_description: The orange slice craft is attached to the front of the white card.

tips: Use a light hand with the glue to avoid warping the paper.
projects.finished_product_description: A decorative card featuring a layered, three-dimensional orange slice design.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up overhead view of a handmade card with a circular, layered paper craft resembling an orange slice, mounted on a white card with a circular cutout. The orange slice has a light blue patterned paper base with pink triangular accents and a central pink circle. A small light blue paper tab is visible on the back of the card, likely for securing the orange slice.

projects.name: Volvelle with Six Slots

steps.instruction: Download the patterns (or enlarge and photocopy the templates on page 141) and print them onto the back side of two sheets of card stock. Cut out the wheel, the square piece, and the small circle using a craft knife and illustrate as desired. Use a sharp blade to ensure clean cutsthis will make the six-slot volvelle fairly easy to assemble. Trim, or miter, the corners on the square piece as indicated, cut on all of the solid interior lines, and score along the lines indicating folds. Cut the third piece of card stock into a 7" (17.8 cm) square. (This will be used to cover the back of the volvelle, hiding the mechanism.)
steps.visual_description: Image 1 shows a square piece of cardstock with a circular cutout in the center, on which a partially cut and scored wheel mechanism is placed. A craft knife and a small circular piece of paper are also visible on a green cutting mat.

tips: Use a sharp blade to ensure clean cuts
projects.finished_product_description: A rotating paper mechanism with six slots.

templates.name: Volvelle templates
templates.shape_description: Includes patterns for a wheel, a square piece, and a small circle.

diagram_descriptions: Image 1 shows a square piece of cardstock with a circular cutout in the center, on which a partially cut and scored wheel mechanism is placed. A craft knife and a small circular piece of paper are also visible on a green cutting mat.

projects.name: Pop-Up Mechanism

steps.instruction: Fold the tab on the wheel piece in half along the score line and glue it to itself using white glue. Draw two small dots on the ends of tabs A and D (in the little boxes beyond the score lines, as indicated) on the front side of the piece.
steps.visual_description: A white circular piece with six numbered slots and tabs. A hand is shown folding and applying glue to one of the tabs. Two small dots are indicated to be drawn on tabs A and D.

steps.instruction: Hold the square piece upside down with the letters oriented so that you can read them and place the wheel (upside down) on top with the numbers oriented so that you can read them, too. Carefully thread tab A (from underneath) through the slot at the top of panel 1. After tab A is in the slot, carefully thread the pull tab through the curved slot at the bottom of the square piece so that it is now on the front side of the mechanism. Make sure the two tabs on either side of the pull tab are not threaded with the pull tab and keep the pull tab in this position as you thread the remaining tabs through the corresponding slots in the wheel.
steps.visual_description: A square piece is held upside down. A circular wheel piece is placed on top. Tab A is being threaded through slot 1 of the wheel. A pull tab is being threaded through a curved slot at the bottom of the square piece.

steps.instruction: Carefully thread tab B (from underneath) through the slot at the top of panel 2. Continue threading tabs C through F into the slots on panels 3 through 6 in this manner. Once all the tabs are slotted through, you should be able to see all the letters on the tabs (A through F).
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the pop-up mechanism showing tabs being threaded through slots on the circular wheel. All six tabs (A-F) are visible.

steps.instruction: Fold the two tabs marked with the dots toward the front along the score lines.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown folding two tabs marked with dots towards the front of the mechanism along score lines.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up mechanism with a wheel and tabs that can be threaded through slots.

diagram_descriptions: Image 2: A hand is applying white glue to a tab on a white circular piece with numbered slots (1-6).
Image 3: A white circular piece with numbered slots (1-6) is placed on top of a white square piece. Tab A is being threaded through slot 1.
Image 4: A white circular piece with numbered slots (1-6) is shown with tabs threaded through the slots. The numbers 1-6 and letters A-F are visible.
Image 5: A close-up view of the center of the pop-up mechanism, showing the tabs threaded through the slots of the circular wheel. The wheel has a decorative pattern.
Image 6: A hand is shown folding a tab on a white piece of cardstock along a score line. The cardstock is on a green cutting mat.

projects.name: Volvelle (rotating disk) Pop-Up Mechanism

steps.instruction: Attach the back panel. Start by gluing the back panel to the folder on one of the folded margins (a glue stick works well for this). Next, put a small dot of white glue on each lettered tab and stick the back panel onto the back of the mechanism, applying pressure (with your hand or a scoring tool) over the areas where you placed the dots of glue in the center. Do not glue the other three folded margins yet.
steps.visual_description: A hand is applying glue from a small bottle to the center of a circular paper mechanism with patterned segments. A small pink circle is visible to the left of the mechanism. The mechanism is on a green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Attach the small circle. Turn the whole mechanism over and place a small dot of white glue on top of the dots printed on the two central tabs that you folded over to the front. Attach the central circle element to the tabs and press firmly.
steps.visual_description: A hand is holding a square piece of cardstock with a circular cutout. Inside the cutout is a rotating disk mechanism with patterned segments. The hand is pressing down on a small pink circle attached to the center of the mechanism.

steps.instruction: Test your mechanism. Slide the tab slowly to the right (A through D). The scene on the wheel should start to appear through the six angled slots. If the mechanism does not slide smoothly, check to see whether there are rough edges along any of the cuts that need trimming. All cuts must be very smooth for the mechanism to operate properly. Once it turns smoothly, fold in the remaining three margins along the edges of the folder and adhere them to the inside of the back panel with a glue stick.
steps.visual_description: Four sequential images (8A, 8B, 8C, 8D) showing a hand sliding a tab on a pop-up mechanism. The mechanism consists of a card base with a rotating disk that reveals different parts of a scene through angled slots as it moves. Image 8A shows the tab being pulled slightly to the right. Image 8B shows the tab pulled further, revealing more of the patterned disk. Image 8C shows the tab pulled even further. Image 8D shows the tab pulled to its furthest extent, revealing the full scene on the disk.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up mechanism called a Volvelle (rotating disk).

diagram_descriptions: Image 7 shows a hand applying glue to the center of a circular paper mechanism on a cutting mat. A small pink circle is to the left.
Image 8A shows a hand holding a card with a rotating disk mechanism, with the tab pulled slightly to the right.
Image 8B shows a hand holding a card with a rotating disk mechanism, with the tab pulled further to the right.
Image 8C shows a hand holding a card with a rotating disk mechanism, with the tab pulled even further to the right.
Image 8D shows a hand holding a card with a rotating disk mechanism, with the tab pulled to its furthest extent.

projects.name: Sleepers, Dreamers & Screamers
projects.finished_product_description: An accordion pop-up book, printed letterpress with hard covers enclosed in a matching clamshell box. The pop-ups are constructed of a variety of papers. The complete text is Weve all had nightmares. Vivid as they may be there is always that sweet release upon waking. But what happens when events in our waking lives surpass even our most horrific dreams. Where is our release now? This book was begun in 2001 and derailed by the events of September 11, 2001. The text was rewritten in the aftermath and finally completed.

projects.name: How Can I Live in Iowa?

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up book open to a scene with a small wooden chair and red curtains. Text on the open pages reads 'We've all had nightmares.' and 'Vivid as they may be'.
A carousel book open to show multiple scenes with houses and landscapes. Text on the open pages reads 'The winters are cold' and 'and seemingly endless.' and 'and rainy in the spring'.
A pop-up book open to a scene with a figure emerging from a boat-like structure. Text on the open pages reads 'surpass even our most' and 'horrific dreams.'
